body: @fkiraly @TonyBagnall @MatthewMiddlehurst @ABostrom @chrisholder I will be very happy to have pointers, and ideally, a clear TSC tutorial (which seems to have disappeared completely!) on the hyper-parameter tuning and cross-validation tasks.

Ideally, they should just work with the sklearn functions? There isn't any fundamental difference between cross-validating/tuning time series data and regular data.

Are there any cases where this does not work currently that you are aware of? We use this sklearn function fine when running our experiments.

`train_probs = cross_val_predict(classifier, X_train, y=y_train, cv=cv_size, method="predict_proba")`

There is still a classification notebook. 

https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/examples/02_classification.ipynb

all classifiers should work with scikit cross validation, although admittedly I have not fully tested this. I  plan to greatly expand the classification notebook in due course, but I can add a section on this sooner than the whole thing. Structurally, it will be identical to scikit learn, but it would be good to present what parameters there are for each algorithm.

dont really see the need for a wrapper, unless you mean a TunedClassifier wrapper such as that we use in tsml https://github.com/uea-machine-learning/tsml/blob/master/src/main/java/machine_learning/classifiers/tuned/TunedClassifier.java

> all classifiers should work with scikit cross validation, although admittedly I have not fully tested this. I plan to greatly expand the classification notebook in due course, but I can add a section on this sooner than the whole thing. Structurally, it will be identical to scikit learn, but it would be good to present what parameters there are for each algorithm.

Are we absolutely certain you can use `sklearn` grid search with `sktime` time series classifiers, and it doesn't jumble the different series together into train/test set?

I'd consider the minimum solution to this a section in the classifier notebook that shows how to do this properly, otherwise users will not know how to do it.

For instance, I also couldn't tell anyone how to do proper grid/random search with the TSC module!

I don't believe anyone has tested the suite of sklearn tuners/cross-validators using the sktime data formats used for TSC. I don't anticipate there being any issue with the classifiers themselves, rather whether the sklearn functions can accept a 3d numpy array, nested dataframe or dataframe with unequal length series.

I personally have not run into any issues, but I haven't looked too deeply into it. At the end of the day, these functions won't have to look at the actual data at all, at most they need to know how many cases are in the input data and be able to move/split the cases. If they are somehow swapping multivariate dimensions around without crashing, they are doing some really funky stuff in those functions.

I agree we should figure out what is available from sklearn and test all of our accepted data formats for TSC on them. Perhaps add a few unit tests.

> I agree we should figure out what is available from sklearn and test all of our accepted data formats for TSC on them. Perhaps add a few tests.

Yes, plus write a tutorial. I can conceive that `numpy3D` and `nested_univ` input can possibly work, because `train_test_split` works on the same index and doesn't care about the rest, but a `sklearn` wrapper will probably not accept any other of our internal data formats.

In that case, a simple wrapper which puts `sklearn` `GridSearchCV` into `_fit` and `_predict` might just do the trick.
